title: What happens when a credit card is dismissed with out prejudice? What does that mean?
question: I had a credit card that would not settle when I tried to. The credit card company charged it off and it went to collections. That collection company supposedly took me to court, but I never got served. Then I realized that this case had been dismissed with out prejudice, but now I'm getting letters from a different collection company. What should I do? Help!
answers:
You may have nothing to worry about if too much time has passed. Credit card company has 4 years from date due or date of last payment, whichever is later, to file suit. If they sent it to collections beyond the 4 years you can stop worrying and tell collectors claim is barred by Statute of Limitations and you will not pay ever.

Depending on how long it has been since your last payment, the debt may be beyond the statute of limitations, and thus time-barred. That does not mean that they cannot call you or report it on your credit, but time-barred means that they may not threaten to sue you or actually sue you. For more information about the debt, I would send letter 1.1 from my sample letters (link below) to the new debt collector, by certified mail, return receipt requested. Of course, always keep copies of your letter and their letters to you in a file or folder.

If you have any further questions, please contact me through my Avvo profile. I have been representing consumers against debt collectors since 1997.

Wait for another lawsuit to be filed unless you want to try to settle it out before another one is filed. You may have a defense of the statute of limitations or other defenses depending on the circumstances.

I am not sure about what happened in your case but generally speaking if a lawsuit is dismissed without prejudice it means it may be refiled at a later time. If it is dismissed with prejudice it cannot be filed again.
